I'm not sure this is a good way to go - you're losing =
test isolation 
 

It seems to me test isolation is not desirable in this c=
ase because the
business logic itself relies on dependencies.  It only make=
s sense to test
that the server is receiving a message if the server starte=
d in the first
place.
 
Consider the following business logic:
 
1) Start s=
erver
2) Create connection pool
3) Send message
4) Receiver of message stor=
es values in the DB
 
In order to test these four steps, it makes sense to =
accumulate the state of
the previous phases so that you don't have to recre=
ate it from scratch.
 
As for the cascade effect, JUnit doesn't allow you t=
o differentiate a test
that failed because it really failed or because a pr=
evious test on which it
depends didn't complete successfully, which is clea=
rly needed in cases like
this.
 
For example, imagine that the connection p=
ool creation fails, JUnit will
tell you "1 SUCCESS, 3 FAILURES" while what =
really happened is "1 SUCCESS, 1
FAILURE, 2 TESTS NOT RUN".
 
At any rate, =
you are right, this definitely sounds like acceptance testing,
not unit tes=
ting, so JUnit is probably not the right tool...
